abstracts.cdata!:
This second phase of the Social Sector
            Programmatic Development Policy Credit (SSPC) series
            continues, through a Development Policy Credit (DPC)
            operation, to support Bolivia's efforts in achieving
            selected Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) through the
            implementation of a number of key social sector policies
            designed during the first phase of this program. The SSPC II
            will support social sector policies, with three broad goals
            in mind: 1) protecting the positive results reached in the
            last decade on increasing access to, and quality of health
            and nutrition, education, water and sanitation, and social
            protection; 2) implementing the sectoral policy frameworks
            designed under the first phase of this programmatic series,
            to continue the progress in social outcomes, and move closer
            to achieving a number of specific MDGs by 2015; and, 3)
            strengthening the capacity of both the Government, and civil
            society to monitor, and evaluate policies, increasing
            accountability and effectiveness. However, country risks
            include, on the political side, the changing political
            situation, and the potential social unrest, as reflected in
            a steady number of protests; the uncertainty on the outcome
            of the Hydrocarbons Law; the country's different views
            on when, and if to call a Constitutional Assembly that would
            discuss, among other things, regional autonomies; and, the
            current crisis related to terminating the contract with the
            company providing water and sanitation services in the
            populous township of El Alto, adjacent to La Paz. In looking
            at the economy, GDP growth remains vulnerable to external
            shocks, notably rising commodity prices and interest rates,
            while institutional weakness aggravate the situation. To
            mitigate this, the Government made concerted efforts to
            address the demands of protesters without resorting to the
            use of force, and has developed and strengthened new
            mechanisms for popular political participation. The Bank and
            the international community have vigorously supported these efforts.
